JAMILA BEGUM (DEAD) THROUGH LEGAL REPRESENTATIVES Versus SHAMI MOHD. (DEAD) THROUGH LEGAL REPRESENTATIVES 727 Appellant; AND ANOTHER Respondents. b Civil Appeal No. 1007 of 2013 t , decided on December 14, 2018 C A. Specific Relief Act, 1963 - S. 31 - Invalidity of a registered sale deed - Onus to prove, in a suit for declaration and cancellation of sale deed - Valid execution of a sale deed - Presumption of, when the same is registered - Plea of absence of free will and volition in execution of sale deed on basis of evidence/medical certificate of doctor - Rejection of, when such doctor had been in practice for only 2 years and was contradicted by the scribe, with Bar experience of 9 years - Held, a registered document carries with it a presumption that it was validly executed and it is for the party challenging the genuineness of the transaction to show that the transaction is not valid in law d - Plaintiff-respondent filed a suit inter alia, for declaration that the sale deed in favour of appellant, in respect of the suit house was void and liable to be cancelled - Held, the sale deed was a registered document and the registration of the sale deed reinforces valid execution of the sale deed - Further, trial court upon consideration and weighing the evidence of advocate and doctor had held that the evidence of advocate was comparatively more acceptable and e believable - Thus, held, first appellate court and High Court ought not to have interfered with the findings recorded by trial court; more so, when the sale deed was a registered document and that they were not right in holding that the sale deed was not validly executed- Evidence Act, 1872- S. 114- Registration Act, 1908, S. 17 (Paras 13 to 20) B. Contract Act, 1872 - S. 16(1) - Undue influence in execution of f contract - Proof of - Proving that one of the parties is in a position to dominate the will of the other - Necessity of, for proving undue influence - Relation with, old age or weak character of executant - If gives rise to any presumption of undue influence - Respondent I-plaintiff contended that the executant of mortgage/sale deed, W, had illicit relationship with appellant J (vendee/mortgagee) and that g he was mentally infirm on the date of the alleged sale deed and that the sale deed was obtained by taking undue advantage of his infirmity and illicit relationship h - Held, merely because the parties are related to each other or merely because the executant was old or of weak character, no presumption of undue influence can arise - Further, the court must scrutinise the pleadings to find out t Arising from the Judgment and O rder in Jamila Begum Nandini v. Family and Personal Laws - Muslim Law - Gift/Hiba - Gift of immovable property - Oral gift without possession - Invalidity of - Held, the conditions for making valid oral gift under the Mohammedan law are: (i) there should be wish or intention on the part of the donor to gift; (ii) acceptance by the donee; and (iii) taking possession of the subject-matter of the gift by the donee - In his suit for declaration that the mortgage deed and the subsequent sale deed executed by his father in favour of the defendant/appellant were void, the plaintiff claimed that the suit property had been orally gifted to him by his father - Held, in the absence of any proof to show that the possession of the suit property was delivered to the plaintiff, the oral gift relied upon by the respondent-plaintiff ought not to have been accepted by the courts below (Paras 23 to 25) Abdul Rahim v. Sk. Abdul Zabar, (2009) 6 sec 160: (2009) 2 sec (Civ) 792,followed D. Limitation Act, 1963 - Art. 59 - Suit for cancellation of sale deed - Period within which can be filed - Held, the plaintiff got knowledge about the execution of the sale deed dt. 21-12-1970 on the third day of death of his father i.e. on 17-5-1971-Thus, the suit must have been filed within three years of the date of knowledge or the date of the sale deed but the suit was filed on 12-7-1978- Therefore, the suit challenging the validity of the mortgage deed dt. 21-11-1967 and sale deed dt. 21-12-1970, barred by limitation - Contract and Specific Relief - Specific Relief Act, 1963, S. 31 (Para 36) E. Property Law - Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - S. 60 - Right of redemption - Extinguishing of, by the act of parties - Held, the right of redemption can be extinguished either by the act of the parties or by decree of a court and the expression "act of parties" refers to some transaction subsequent to the mortgage, standing barred [i.e. being distinct] from the mortgage transaction - W duly executed a mortgage deed in favour of J and S - Subsequently, J, purchased the property by a sale deed - In the present case, held, J having purchased the entire right of redemption by the execution of the sale deed, the mortgage qua the appellant (son of mortgagor/seller) merged with the sale - Also, High Court could not have passed the decree for re demption without following the procedure laid down in Or. 34 Rr. 7 and 8 CPC - Civil Procedure Code, 1908, Or. 34 Rr. 7 & 8 (Paras 32 to 35) a b C d e f g h ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. The mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 (Ext. 74 Kha.) was executed by W for Rs 11,000 in favour of J and S. DW 4, H, attesting witness of the mortgage deed was examined who has stated about the execution of mortgage deed by Wand thus, the appellants have proved the execution of mortgage deed in accordance with law. (Para 13) Sale deed dated 21-12-1970 in favour of J is a registered document and the registration of the sale deed reinforces valid execution of the sale deed. (Para 16) Prem Singh v. Birbal, (2006) 5 SCC 353; Vishwanath Bapurao Sabale v. Shalinibai Nagappa Sabale, (2009) 12 sec 101 : (2009) 4 sec (Civ) 646, relied on From the evidence of Dr W (PW 5) and from his medical certificate, Ext. 50 Kha., the respondent-plaintiff has thus tried to show that at the time of the execution of the sale deed, W was not in such a position to apply his mind and understand the contents of the sale deed. Dr W was doing private practice from the year 1969 and that at the time of issuing medical certificate, he had experience of medical practice for only two years. (Para 17) At the time of writing the sale deed, Advocate Ahmad (DW 3) was having Bar experience of nine years. In his evidence, DW 3, Shri Ahmad has stated that on the instruction of W, he had prepared the sale deed and that sale deed was validly executed by W out of his free will and consent. (Para 19) Upon appreciation of oral evidence, when the trial court has recorded the findings that the evidence of Advocate Ahmad (DW 3) is credible and acceptable, the first appellate court and the High Court ought not to have interfered with the findings recorded by the trial court; more so, when the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 was a registered document. (Para 20) Whether there was a valid oral gift in favour of the respondent-plaintiff SM as claimed? During the period between 1970 to 1978, the appellant-defendant J was asserting her right over the suit property in various eviction proceedings against plaintiffs-SM, NB and N and some tenants. (Para 21) The tenants were in occupation of the suit house. The respondent-plaintiff has not proved as to how at the time of oral gift, the possession was delivered to him. Nothing is brought on record to show that Respondent 1 SM has taken any steps to get the property mutated in his name. Likewise, nothing is brought on record to show that pursuant to the oral gift, the respondent-plaintiff collected rent from the tenants or paid house tax, water tax, etc. (Para 24) Subhas Chandr Das Mushib v. Ganga Prasad Das Mushib , AIR 1967 SC 878; Shivdev Singh v. Sucha Singh, (2000) 4 SCC 326; Vinod Kumar v. Gangadhar, (2015) 1 SCC 391 : (2015) 1 SCC (Civ) 521; B. V. Nagesh v. H. V. BANUMATHI, J.- This appeal arises out of the judgment dated 7-9-2007 1 passed by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad dismissing Second Appeal No. 135 of 1998 thereby upholding the oral gift by Wali Mohd. in favour of Respondent I-plaintiff and the will dated 30-9-1970 and directing the original plaintiff-deceased Respondent 1 to pay the mortgage amount of Rs 11,000 and holding that the mortgage dated 21-11-1967 registered on 12-1-1968 shall stand redeemed and further directing the appellant-defendants to handover the vacant possession of the property. 2. Facts giving rise to this appeal are that deceased Respondent 1, Shami Mohd. filed OS No. 130 of 1978 against the appellant and one Sakina (deceased predecessor-in-interest of Respondents 2 to 11) for declaration that the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 and also sale deed dated 21-12-1970 in favour of appellant, Jamila Begum in respect of the suit house is void and consequently to cancel the sale deed. In the alternative, the respondent-plaintiff claimed redemption of the mortgage, in case, that the mortgage is held to be valid. 3. The case of the respondent-plaintiff is that Wali Mohd., father of Respondent 1 had purchased two plots and along with Respondent 1 got the disputed house constructed which was gifted to Respondent 1 through an oral gift on 30-9-1970 and he was put in possession. On the very same day, a will was also executed in favour of N ababun, stepmother of Respondent 1 in respect of certain properties and in the said will, Wali Mohd. also mentioned about the oral gift. Respondent I-plaintiff further averred that though the appellants 1 Jamila Begum Nandini v. ( Banumathi, J.) 731 contend that Wali Mohd. had executed a mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 in respect of the suit property in favour of the appellant and one Sakina for a a sum of Rs 11,000, Wali Mohd. was not in requirement of money and the alleged mortgage deed was got executed without consideration. Respondent 1 has alleged that the appellant was the mistre ss of Abdul Rahim who is husband of Sakina. It is further averred that the said Abdul Rahim and Wali Mohd. were friends and because of this, the appellant got the said usufructuary mortgage deed executed in her name and Sakina in collusion with Abdul Rahim and as b C d e f g h such no money was advanced under the said mortgage deed and the same was obtained by fraud and undue influence. 4. Resisting the suit, the appellant filed written statement inter alia contending that Nababun is not the legally wedded wife of Wali Mohd. and that she was simply his maidservant. It was averred that Wali Mohd. never executed any will in favour ofN ababun. Further, it was stated that Respondent 1 was not in possession of the disputed house. Since 1960, relations between Wali Mohd. and Respondent 1 were strained and Wali Mohd. had turned out Respondent 1 from the suit house and had also lodged FIR against him. Wali Mohd. duly executed mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 for Rs 11,000 in favour of Jamila Begum and Sakina. Wali Mohd. had sold the suit property in favour of the appellant for consideration of Rs 30,000 and executed the sale deed dated 21-12-1970. After the sale deed in her favour, the appellant had continually exercised acts of ownership and the suit filed in the year 1978 challenging the mortgage deed and sale deed dated 21-12-1970 is barred by limitation. S. Upon consideration of evidence, the trial court dismissed the suit holding that the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 was legal and valid. It was also held that the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 was executed for due consideration of Rs 30,000 and the same cannot be assailed on the ground of undue influence or inadequate consideration. The trial court also held that a suit for cancellation of sale deed has to be filed within the period of limitation of three years and the suit filed in the year 1978 challenging the sale deed of the year 1970 is barred by limitation. The trial court held that the alleged will cannot be accepted since it does not bear the signature of the scribe and was not registered. The trial court rejected the stand of plaintiff-Respondent 1, Shami Mohd. that the suit house was jointly constructed by Wali Mohd. and Respondent 1. The trial court also held that the contents of the will that N ababun is the second wife of Wali Mohd. is also not correct in the light of statement of Respondent 1 where he specifically stated that after the death of his mother, his father did not remarry. 6. In appeal, the first appellate court allowed the appeal by holding that Wali Mohd. had no necessity to mortgage or sell the suit property for such inadequate consideration of Rs 30,000. The first appellate court placed burden of proof upon appellant Jamila Begum that she had to prove the genuineness of the mortgage deed as well as sale deed dated 21-12-1970 and that they were validly executed by Wali Mohd. and the said burden has not been discharged by the appellant. Insofar as the oral gift and will dated 30-9-1970 in favour of Nababun relied upon by the respondent-plaintiff, the first appellate court ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. The first appellate court set aside both mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 and also the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 and reversed the judgment of the trial court and thereby allowed the appeal. 7. In the second appeal, the High Court affirmed the judgment of the first appellate court by holding that the suit property was of large extent and it could not have been sold for such inadequate consideration of Rs 30,000 and the appellant failed to discharge the burden cast on her of proving that the sale deed was validly executed. The High Court affirmed the findings of the first appellate court that oral gift in favour of Respondent 1 had been proved whereas, the alleged mortgage deed and the sale deed were sham and void documents. The High Court also held that the respondent-plaintiff is entitled to redeem the mortgage and directed him to pay the mortgage amount ofRs 11,000 for redemption of mortgage and also ordered delivery of possession. 8. Mr R.B. Singhal, learned Senior Counsel for the appellant submitted that the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 has been executed for due consideration and the first appellate court and the High Court erred in placing the burden of proof upon the appellant. It was submitted that when the respondent-plaintiff assailed the document as vitiated by fraud and undue influence, burden lay upon Respondent 1 to establish coercion and undue influence. It was submitted that the plaintiff failed to establish that appellant Jamila Begum was in a position to influence Wali Mohd. to get the sale deed executed in her favour. 9. It was further submitted by Mr Singhal that the alleged oral gift and will dated 30-9-1970 has not been proved and is clearly an afterthought. It was contended that delivery of possession which is the essential ingredient of oral gift has not been established by the respondent-plaintiff. The learned Senior Counsel further submitted that the suit filed in the year 1978 for cancellation of the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 and the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 is barred by limitation. 10. Refuting the contentions, Mr Braj Kishore Mishra, learned counsel for the respondents submitted that the first appellate court being a final fact-finding court has found that the respondent-plaintiff has proved the oral gift whereas, the alleged mortgage deed and the sale deed were sham and void documents and the same cannot be assailed. It was further submitted that within three years after execution of the mortgage deed by Wali Mohd., sale of the property on the ground that he was unable to rede em the mortgage is unbelievable. 11. It was further contended by Mr Mishra that there were two mortgagees viz. Jamila Begum and Sakina, whereas the sale deed was executed only in favour of the appellant Jamila Begum and there is nothing to show that the other mortgagee had given possession of her part in the suit property to the appellant Jamila Begum. It was further submitted that the High Court rightly decreed the prayer for redemption of mortgage and the findings of fact recorded by the first appellate court and affirmed by the High Court cannot be said to be erroneous. It was contended that as per Article 61 of the Schedule to the Limitation Act, 1963 period of thirty years has been prescribed as limitation for filing suit for a b C d e f g h ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. ( Banumathi, J.) 733 redemption of mortgage and the suit filed in the year 1978 within eight years of the sale deed was well within time and the High Court was right and justified in granting the redemption of mortgage to the respondent-plaintiff. 12. We have perused the impugned judgment1 and the materials on record. Upon consideration of submission, the following points arise for consideration: 12.1. (i) Whether the first appellate court and the High Court were right in placing the burden of proof upon the appellant to prove that the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 was validly executed by Wali Mohd. with his free will and that the appellant has not discharged that burden cast upon her? 12.2. (ii) Whether the High Court and the first appellate court were right in accepting the case of the plaintiff that Wali Mohd. orally gifted the suit house to the plaintiff and also executed the will on 30-9-1970 in favour of N ababun and rejecting the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 relied upon by the appellant- defendant? 12.3. (iii) Whether the High Court was right in granting the alternative relief of redemption of mortgage deed on payment of Rs 11,000 the amount mentioned in the mortgage deed tre ating the suit as suit simpliciter for redemption of mortgage? 12.4. (iv) Whether the suit OS No. 130 of 1978 filed by the respondent- plaintiff in the year 1978 to set a side the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 and sale deed dated 21-12-1970 was barred by limitation? 12.5. (v) Whether the impugned judgment 1 of the High Court is sustainable? Mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 and sale deed dated 21-12-1970-Whether valid and execution duly proved? 13. The mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 (Ext. 74 Kha.) was executed by Wali Mohd. for Rs 11,000 in favour of Jamila Begum and Sakina. DW 4, Abdul Hamid, attesting witness of the mortgage deed was examined who has stated about the execution of mortgage deed by Wali Mohd. and thus , the appellants have proved the execution of mortgage deed in accordance with law. There is also mention about the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 in the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 and that Wali Mohd. was not in a position to repay the mortgage deed amount of Rs 11,000. Respondent I-plaintiff Shami Mohd. has not adduced any reliable evidence of proof to establish that the mortgage deed was not executed by Wali Mohd. out of his free will or without any consideration. 14. Wali Mohd. sold the suit property for Rs 30,000 to the appellant Jamila Begum by a registered sale deed dated 21-12-1970 (Ext. 75 Kha.). The recitals in the registered sale deed are natural and cogent showing that it was validly executed by Wali Mohd. The sale deed refers to the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 and that Wali Mohd. received Rs 11,000 from the mortgagees -Jamila Begum and Sakina. Recitals in the sale deed also refer to the fact that the house was in the possession of the tenants and that the rental income was 1 Jamila Begum Nandini v. The recitals in the sale deed make a clear reference to the receipt of sale consideration ofRs 30,000 as: (i) that the vendor Wali Mohd. had received the mortgage amount of Rs 11,000 and that he had not been able to get the property released from mortgage; (ii) receipt of consideration of Rs 11,000 from the purchaser at the time of entering into the agreement to sell; and (iii) receipt of consideration amount of Rs 8000 in the presence of Sub-Registrar, Kanpur at the time of execution of the sale deed. 15. In the sale deed dated 21-12-1970, vendor Wali Mohd. had stated that he had executed the sale deed out of his free will and volition. The relevant recitals of sale dee d dated 21-12-1970 read as under: " ... Therefore, in my full senses and in disposing mind and body and without any pressure or coercion from anybody, I execute this agreement to sell, of my own will, for a consideration of Rs 30,000 (Rupees thirty thousand only) in favour of Smt Jamila alias Nandani so that it may be of use when the need arises." 16. Sale deed dated 21-12-1970 in favour of Jamila Begum is a registered document and the registration of the sale deed reinforces valid execution of the sale deed. A registered document carries with it a presumption that it was validly executed. It is for the party challenging the genuineness of the transaction to show that the transaction is not valid in law. In Prem Singh v. Birbal2 , it was held as under: (SCC pp. 360-61, para 27) "27. There is a presumption that a registered document is validly executed. A registered document, therefore, prima facie would be valid in law. The onus of proof, thus, would be on a person who leads evidence to rebut the presumption. In the instant case, Respondent 1 has not been able to rebut the said presumption." The above judgment in Prem Singh case2 has been referred to in Vishwanath Bapu rao Sabale v. Shalinibai Nagappa Sabale 3 . 17. The contention of the respondent-plaintiff is that at the time of the execution of the sale deed, Wali Mohd. was mentally weak and therefore, he was not in a position to understand and that the sale deed was not executed out of his free will and volition. To substantiate their case, Respondent I- plaintiff has examined Dr Wasim (PW 5) who has stated that he has treated Wali Mohd. from the period 15-11-1970 to 25-12-1970 and produced the medical certificate, Ext. 50 Kha. From the evidence of Dr Wasim (PW 5) and from his medical certificate, Ext. 50 Kha., the respondent-plaintiff has thus tried to show that at the time of the execution of the sale deed, Wali Mohd. was not in such a position to apply his mind and understand the contents of the sale deed. As pointed out by the trial court, Dr Wasim was doing private practice from the year 1969 and that at the time of issuing medical certificate, he had experience of medical practice for only two years. Dr Wasim has admitted that he was not knowing Wali Mohd. from before. ( Banumathi, J.) 735 Dr Wasim, it is brought in evidence that Dr Wasim did not prepare the medical certificate, Ext. 50 Kha. after seeing the prescriptions written and maintained by him during illness of Wali Mohd.; but he prepared the same only on the basis of his memory. Dr Wasim also clarified that about 10-15 days prior to the treatment of Wali Mohd., Dr K.N. Srivastava and Dr Sikka also treated Wali Mohd. but the other two doctors were not examined, though Dr Sikka was stated to be in Kanpur. 18. The trial court also referred to Exts. 44 Kha. to 49 Kha. and Ext. 51 Kha. filed by the respondent-plaintiff to show about the illness of Wali Mohd., all of which relate to the period from March 1971 to June 1971. The prescriptions relate to the period from March 1971 to June 1971. After referring to these documents, the trial court observed that the condition of Wali Mohd. started deteriorating after March 1971. From the evidence of Dr Wasim and the medical certificate, Ext. 50 Kha. issued by him, it cannot be said that Wali Mohd. was not mentally fit at the time of execution of the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 and that the same was not validly executed. 19. On the contrary, the appellant-defendant has examined Advocate Ahmad (DW 3) who has prepared the sale deed and the scribe of sale deed dated 21-12-1970. At the time of writing the sale deed, Advocate Ahmad (DW 3) was having Bar experience of nine years. In his evidence, DW 3, Shri Ahmad has stated that on the instruction of Wali Mohd., h e had prepared the sale deed and that sale deed was validly executed by Wali Mohd. out of his free will and consent. As pointed out by the trial court, DW 3, Advocate Ahmad was personally knowing Wali Mohd. and that being the scribe of the sale deed, Ext. 75 Kha. contains the signature of DW 3, Shri Ahmad, Advocate. 20. Under the Mohammedan law, no doubt, making oral gift is permissible. The conditions for making valid oral gift under the Mohammedan law are: (i) there should be wish or intention on the part of the donor to gift; (ii) acceptance by the donee; and (iii) taking possession of the subject-matter of the gift by the donee. The three stages for consideration of a case of undue influence were expounded in Raghunath Prasad Sahu v. Sarju Prasad Sahu 6 in the following words: (SCC OnLine PC) 'In the first place the relations between the parties to each other must be such that one is in a position to dominate the will of the other. Once that position is substantiated the second stage has been reached viz. the issue whether the contract has been induced by undue influence. Upon the determination of this issue a third point emerges, which is that of the onus probandi. If the transaction appears to be unconscionable, then the burden of proving that the contract was not induced by undue influence is to lie upon the person who was in a position to dominate the will of the other. Error is almost sure to arise if the order of these propositions be change d. The unconscionableness of the bargain is not the first thing to be considered. The first thing to be considered is the relations of these parties. Were they such as to put one in a position to dominate the will of the other?' " 30. Section 60 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 provides that at any time after the money becomes due, the mortgagor has a right, on payment or tender, at a proper time and place, of the mortgage-money to require the mortgagee to deliver the mortgage deed and all documents relating to the mortgaged property, and where the mortgagee is in possession of the mortgaged property, to deliver possession thereof to the mortgagor. In Shivdev Singh v. Sucha Singh 7, it was held as under: (SCC p. 330, para 8) "8. . .. The right of redemption recognised under the Transfer of Property Act is thus a statutory and legal right which cannot be extinguished by any agreement made at the time of mortgage as part of the mortgage transaction." 33. The right of redemption can be extinguished as provided in the proviso to Section 60 of the Transfer of Property Act. It can be extinguished either by the act of the parties or by decree of a court. The expression "act of parties" refers to some transaction subsequent to the mortgage, standing barred from the mortgage transaction. As discussed earlier, in this case Jamila Begum, one of the mortgagees has purchased the property by the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 and thus, she purchased the entire equity * of redemption by the execution of the sale deed, the mortgage qua the appellant has merged with the sale. 34. On behalf of Respondent I-plaintiff, an argument was advanced that, by the subsequent sale the appellant could not have purchased the entire property since there were two mortgagees viz. Jamila Begum and Sakina and therefore, the appellant could not have derived title over the entire suit property. We find no merit in the above contention, property purchased by the appellant Jamila Begum from Wali Mohd. by sale deed dated 21-12-1970 is an act of the parties, by which the right of redemption qua the appellant became extinguished by the act of the parties. Without keeping in view the main relief sought in the suit, the High Court was not right in decreeing the suit for redemption of mortgage. 35. The High Court has not followed the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure for passing decree for redemption of mortgage. Order 34 Rule 7 CPC stipulates that in a suit for redemption of mortgage, the court shall prepare the preliminary decree in accordance with Order 34 Rule 7 CPC. The High Court has passed a decree for redemption of mortgage simpliciter without following the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure. The High Court also erred in directing the delivery of possession of the suit property to Respondent 1- 7 (2000) 4 sec 326 * Ed.: The right of redemption in India after the enactment of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, is no longer merely an equitable estate, but as observed in Shivdev Singh case, (2000) 4 SCC 326, a b C d e f and also set out in para 32b-c, above, "The right of redemption recognised under the Transfer of g Property Act is thus a statutory and legal right ... ". The misnomer of "equity of redemption" has carried on because until the passage of the TPA, 1882, following the English position of law, the right of redemption was not a legal proprietary right, but only recognised as an equitable estate and could hence be defeated by bona fide purchasers for valuable consideration. This position changed with the passing of the TPA, 1882, and as observed in para 34 below, it is now "the right of redemption". The key difference between a legal proprietary estate and an equitable proprietary estate being that a legal proprietary estate is indefeasible and binds the whole world/third parties h irrespective of their notice, knowledge or consent, while an equitable proprietary estate binds the whole world/third parties except bona fide purchasers for valuable consideration. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Suit barred by limitation 36. As discussed, the suit was filed for declaration that the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 as well as sale deed dated 21-12-1970 executed by Wali Mohd. were not executed by him out of his free will and are void. In Para (14) of the plaint, it is averred that the cause of action of the suit arose on 21-11-1967 and 21-12-1970. Under Articles 58 and 59 of the Schedule to the Limitation Act, 1963 in a suit filed for any declaration is to be filed within three years when the right to sue accrues. Under Article 59 of the Limitation Act, suit filed to cancel or set aside the instrument or decree, the suit has to be filed within three years from the date when the facts entitling the plaintiff to set aside or cancel the instrument or decree became first known to him. Plaintiff Shami Mohd. has admitted in his evidence that he got knowledge about the execution of the sale deed dated 21-12-1970 on the third day of death of his father on 17-5-1971. The suit must have been filed within three years of the date of knowledge or the date of the sale deed but the suit was filed on 12-7-1978. In the case in hand, the suit filed challenging the validity of the mortgage deed dated 21-11-1967 and sale deed dated 21-12-1970 is beyond the period of limitation of three years as prescribed under Articles 58 and 59 of the Schedule to the Limitation Act and barred by limitation. 37. The appellate court has jurisdiction to reverse or affirm the findings of the trial court. The first appeal is a valuable right of the parties and unless restricted by law, the whole case is therein open for rehearing both on questions of fact and law. The judgment of the appellate court must, therefore, reflect its conscious application of mind and record findings supported by reasons, on all the issues arising along with the contentions put forth, and pressed by the parties for decision of the appellate court. Sitting as a court of first appeal, it was the duty of the High Court to deal with all the issues and the evidence led by the parties before recording its finding s . The first appeal is a valuable right and the parties have a right to be heard both on questions of law and on facts and the judgment in the first appeal must address itself to all the issues of law and fact and decide it by giving reasons in support of the findings. (Vide Santosh Hazari v. Purushottam Tiwari 10 , SCC p. 188, para 15 and Madhukar v. Sangram 11 SCC p. 758, para 5.)' " 39. The court of first appeal has jurisdiction to reverse or affirm the findings of the trial court. When the court of first appeal takes a different view, the judgment of the first appellate court must show the conscious application of mind and record its findings based on the evidence adduced by the parties and the judgment must record the reasons as to why the first appellate court differs from the judgment of the trial court. In this case, the judgment of the lower appellate court has not answered all the points arising for determination and the evidence adduced thereon. Likewise, the High Court has not recorded any finding either on fact or on law. The High Court proceeded on the footing as if the suit was a simple suit for redemption of mortgage. Without appreciation of evidence adduced by the parties and sale deed dated 21-12-1970, the High Court erred in ordering the redemption of mortgage and delivery of possession. The impugned judgment1 of the High Court cannot be sustained and is liable to be set aside. 40. In the result, the impugnedjudgment of the High Court in Jamila Begum Nandini v.
